lessonActivities.title: Welcome to the Time Machine!
lessonActivities.content:
Past Perfect = the tense that goes BEFORE the Past Simple. It’s how native speakers tell stories in the correct order!

When the police arrived, the thief had escaped.
→ First: thief escaped → Then: police arrived

Form: had + past participle (had gone, had seen, had forgotten…)

Fun fact: Without Past Perfect, your story sounds like a robot wrote it!
examples: By the time I woke up, my family had eaten breakfast.
She was happy because she had passed the exam.
I had never seen the sea before 2015.
lessonActivities.tips: Ask yourself: Which happened FIRST? → Past Perfect!

lessonActivities.title: Past Perfect Simple vs Continuous
lessonActivities.content:
Simple = completed result (how many? finished?)

I’d written three emails before the meeting.

Continuous = long activity → you’re tired / room is messy

I’d been writing emails all morning — my eyes hurt!

Live / work / study / teach → both possible!
examples: He’d cooked dinner. (food ready)
He’d been cooking for hours. (kitchen destroyed!)
They’d lived in Paris for 10 years = They’d been living in Paris for 10 years.

lessonActivities.title: Magic Words that SCREAM Past Perfect
lessonActivities.content:
These words almost FORCE you to use Past Perfect:

  • by the time
  • already (in the past)
  • never … before
  • until then
  • the first time … was

Unlike Present Perfect → you CAN use exact years!
examples: By the time we arrived, the party had finished.
She had already left when I called.
I had never eaten sushi before 2018.

lessonActivities.title: Before / After Rule (The Secret Native Speakers Use)
lessonActivities.content:
If you use before or after, Past Perfect is OPTIONAL!

Both correct:

→ After she had finished homework, she watched TV.
→ After she finished homework, she watched TV.

But Past Perfect sounds more professional and dramatic!
examples: Before I met Lisa, I had never fallen in love. (dramatic!)
Before I met Lisa, I never fell in love. (simple, OK)

lessonActivities.title: Used to = Old Habits & States That Stopped
lessonActivities.content:
Used to + verb = something regular in the past, but NOT now.

Works with ACTION verbs AND STATE verbs (be, have, like, live…)

Negative & question → DID!
examples: I used to smoke. (but I quit)
She used to be shy. (state → only used to!)
Did you use to live in Jakarta?

lessonActivities.title: Would = Repeated Actions (Storytelling Gold!)
lessonActivities.content:
Would = repeated actions in the past (ONLY actions, NOT states!)

Often with time expressions: every summer, when I was young, on Sundays…

Shows nostalgia, annoyance, or extreme habits!
examples: Every weekend we would go fishing.
My brother would always steal my toys! (annoying!)
I would never eat vegetables as a child.

lessonActivities.title: Used to vs Would — The Golden Rule
lessonActivities.content:
Used to → habits AND states
Would → only repeated ACTIONS (and needs time context)

Wrong: I would be shy. Correct: I used to be shy.
examples: I used to have long hair. (state)
When I was 10, I would ride my bike every day. (action)
Grandma would make cookies every Sunday.

lessonActivities.title: Past Perfect with Duration (Live, Work, Study, Own…)
lessonActivities.content:
Even with non-continuous verbs, we use Past Perfect for duration up to a past moment.

By 2020, he had been in London for 8 years.
We had had that car for 10 years before it broke.
examples: They had owned the house for 40 years.
She had been a teacher for 15 years when she retired.

lessonActivities.title: Common Mistakes (Indonesian Special!)
lessonActivities.content:
Wrong: When I arrived, the train left. (no order!)
Wrong: I had never see snow. (missing -n)
Wrong: I would be fat. (state!)

Fix them and sound like a native!
examples: Correct: When I arrived, the train had left.
Correct: I had never seen snow before.

lessonActivities.title: Your Turn: Become a Master Storyteller!
lessonActivities.content: Now write a dramatic story about a day everything went wrong… or your childhood… or life before a big change. Use everything: Past Perfect, Continuous, used to, would, already, never before!

writingActivities.question: First-time experiences: Write 6 sentences using “I had never … before” + Past Perfect Simple.
writingActivities.hint: I had never flown on a plane before 2019.
sentenceStarters: It was the first time I had ___

writingActivities.question: By the time / Already drama: Write 6 sentences using “By the time …” or “already” in the past + Past Perfect.
writingActivities.hint: By the time I arrived, the movie had already started.
sentenceStarters: By the time I got home ___

writingActivities.question: Regrets & wishes: Write 6 sentences beginning with “I wish I had …” or “If only I hadn’t …”.
writingActivities.hint: I wish I had studied harder for the exam.

writingActivities.question: Childhood repeated actions: Write 8 sentences — 4 with “would” (repeated actions) and 4 with “used to”.
writingActivities.hint: Every Sunday we would go fishing / I used to collect stickers.
sentenceStarters: When I was young, I would ___

writingActivities.question: Tired, dirty, crying… Write 6 sentences using Past Perfect Continuous to explain why someone looked that way.
writingActivities.hint: He was exhausted because he’d been working all night.
sentenceStarters: She was crying because she’d been ___
His hands were dirty because he’d been ___
I was out of breath because I’d been ___

writingActivities.question: Duration before a past moment: Write 6 sentences using live/work/study/teach/have/own + for/since + Past Perfect (Simple or Continuous).
writingActivities.hint: She had worked there for 10 years when she got promoted.
sentenceStarters: He had worked at the company ___ when
They had owned the car ___ before

writingActivities.question: The worst day ever: Write a short paragraph (7–10 sentences) about a day everything went wrong. Use: 3 Past Perfect Simple, 2 Continuous, 1 already.
writingActivities.hint: When I woke up, my phone had already died… I’d been studying all night…
sentenceStarters: I was late because I’d been ___

writingActivities.question: Life before a big change: Write 8 sentences about your life BEFORE moving house / starting university / meeting your best friend, etc. Use Past Perfect + used to/would.
writingActivities.hint: Before I moved to Jakarta, I had never taken a train… I used to ride a bicycle every day…
sentenceStarters: In my old town, I would ___

writingActivities.question: Mixed storytelling challenge: Write a short true story (8–10 sentences) about something that happened to you or your family. Use: 3 Past Perfect Simple, 2 Continuous, 1 used to, 1 would, 1 never…before, 1 already.
sentenceStarters: I will never forget the day ___
Before that moment, I had never ___

writingActivities.question: Final boss: Diary entry from 5 years ago. Write a diary paragraph (10+ sentences) as if it’s 5 years ago, looking back at your life before that. Use everything you learned!
writingActivities.hint: Dear Diary, 5 years ago today… I had just… I’d been dreaming… I used to think…
sentenceStarters: Dear Diary, five years ago today ___
Looking back, I wish I had ___

gameActivities.question: Two hours of cooking - focus on the duration and process, not just completion.
gameActivities.sentence: When I arrived, she ____ ____ dinner for two hours.
gameActivities.hint: Focus on duration and ongoing process, not completion

gameActivities.question: What's the source of exhaustion - a completed task or the long effort itself?
gameActivities.sentence: I was exhausted because I ____ ____ all day.
gameActivities.hint: Exhaustion shows in the result of prolonged activity

gameActivities.question: Three reports - can you count them? Think about finished results.
gameActivities.sentence: By 10 PM, they ____ ____ three reports.
gameActivities.hint: Count the result (three reports) - completed or ongoing?

gameActivities.question: Her dirty hands are visible proof. What explains this physical evidence?
gameActivities.sentence: Her hands were dirty because she ____ ____ in the garden.
gameActivities.hint: Dirty hands = evidence of the activity itself

gameActivities.question: Five years in Tokyo - stating a completed period of residence.
gameActivities.sentence: He ____ ____ in Tokyo for 5 years when he got the promotion.
gameActivities.hint: With 'live', stating completed periods uses one form more naturally

gameActivities.question: Their first time seeing snow - a completed experience or ongoing weather?
gameActivities.sentence: The children were excited because it ____ ____ for the first time.
gameActivities.hint: First time experiences are completed events

gameActivities.question: Your eyes hurt from hours of reading - what caused this physical strain?
gameActivities.sentence: My eyes hurt because I ____ ____ ____ for hours.
gameActivities.hint: Physical pain results from prolonged activity

gameActivities.question: Five emails before the meeting - emphasis on how many got done.
gameActivities.sentence: She ____ ____ five emails before the meeting started.
gameActivities.hint: When you can count results, think about accomplishment

gameActivities.question: Kitchen destroyed! The mess tells a story about what happened during cooking.
gameActivities.sentence: The kitchen was a mess because he ____ ____ ____ all morning.
gameActivities.hint: Messy kitchen = evidence of the process, not just the result

gameActivities.question: Twelve years of study by graduation - stating the total time period.
gameActivities.sentence: By graduation, I ____ ____ English for 12 years.
gameActivities.hint: For stating completed time periods with study, one form is more common

gameActivities.question: They're late because of the searching itself, not because they found parking.
gameActivities.sentence: They were late because they ____ ____ ____ for parking.
gameActivities.hint: The search process caused lateness

gameActivities.question: She's confident because preparation is done, ready for action.
gameActivities.sentence: She felt confident because she ____ ____ well.
gameActivities.hint: Confidence comes from finished preparation being ready

gameActivities.question: He's sweating - clear physical proof of recent exertion.
gameActivities.sentence: He was sweating because he ____ ____ ____.
gameActivities.hint: Sweating is visible evidence of recent physical activity

gameActivities.question: The whole project by midnight - everything accomplished and finished.
gameActivities.sentence: By midnight, we ____ ____ the whole project.
gameActivities.hint: Focus on the accomplished result

gameActivities.question: Frustration from an hour of unsuccessful attempts - the struggle continues.
gameActivities.sentence: I was frustrated because I ____ ____ ____ to fix it for an hour.
gameActivities.hint: Frustration comes from the ongoing unsuccessful effort

gameActivities.question: Players exhausted from playing without rest - the non-stop effort shows.
gameActivities.sentence: The players were tired because they ____ ____ ____ without a break.
gameActivities.hint: Tiredness from sustained exertion without stopping

gameActivities.question: Reading it three times led to understanding - count the repetitions.
gameActivities.sentence: She understood it because she ____ ____ the explanation three times.
gameActivities.hint: Three times = specific number of completed readings

gameActivities.question: Aching fingers tell the story - hours of piano practice left their mark.
gameActivities.sentence: My fingers ached because I ____ ____ ____ the piano for hours.
gameActivities.hint: Physical ache is evidence of sustained practice

gameActivities.question: Homework done before she called - task accomplished and complete.
gameActivities.sentence: By the time she called, I ____ ____ my homework.
gameActivities.hint: Homework is complete, task accomplished

gameActivities.question: Wet road in the morning - what does this tell you about the night's weather?
gameActivities.sentence: The road was wet because it ____ ____ ____ all night.
gameActivities.hint: Wet road = visible evidence of weather activity overnight

gameActivities.question: Twenty years in one house before selling - stating the duration of residence.
gameActivities.sentence: We ____ ____ in that house for 20 years when we sold it.
gameActivities.hint: Stating how long you resided somewhere before a past moment

gameActivities.question: His confused look shows the mental effort - he's still trying to understand.
gameActivities.sentence: He looked confused because he ____ ____ ____ to understand.
gameActivities.hint: Confusion visible from the ongoing mental struggle

gameActivities.question: By 2020, four children in the family - stating a situation that existed.
gameActivities.sentence: By 2020, they ____ ____ four children.
gameActivities.hint: Having children as possession, not an activity - think about states

gameActivities.question: Feeling sick from the amount eaten - too much food consumed.
gameActivities.sentence: I felt sick because I ____ ____ too much.
gameActivities.hint: The amount eaten caused sickness, not the eating process

gameActivities.question: Angry because of being ignored all day - the neglect went on and on.
gameActivities.sentence: She was angry because he ____ ____ ____ her calls all day.
gameActivities.hint: The ongoing neglect throughout the day caused anger

gameActivities.question: Two movies watched - count them, both finished before going home.
gameActivities.sentence: They ____ ____ two movies before they went home.
gameActivities.hint: Number of movies completed

gameActivities.question: Hoarse voice from singing all evening - his voice shows the strain.
gameActivities.sentence: His voice was hoarse because he ____ ____ ____ all evening.
gameActivities.hint: Hoarse voice = physical consequence of prolonged singing

gameActivities.question: Relief because the answer was found - success achieved, problem solved.
gameActivities.sentence: We were relieved because we ____ ____ the answer.
gameActivities.hint: Relief from achieving success, not from the search

gameActivities.question: Tall grass from weeks of neglect - nobody maintained it over time.
gameActivities.sentence: The grass was tall because nobody ____ ____ ____ it for weeks.
gameActivities.hint: Think about the absence of an action over a period

gameActivities.question: BOSS: Years of studying but never traveled - duration of learning vs. life experience.
gameActivities.sentence: I ____ ____ ____ English for years, but I ____ never ____ abroad.
gameActivities.hint: First: emphasis on duration of study. Second: life experience up to that point

quizActivities.question: What tense shows which action happened first in the past?
quizActivities.sentence: When the police arrived, the thief ____.
quizActivities.hint: Ask yourself: Which happened FIRST? The thief left before the police came. Use Past Perfect (had + past participle).
quizActivities.explanation: Past Perfect shows the action that happened first. The thief escaped BEFORE the police arrived, so use 'had escaped'.

quizActivities.question: Which form emphasizes the completed result?
quizActivities.sentence: By the time I woke up, my family ____ breakfast.
quizActivities.hint: 'By the time' signals Past Perfect. Use Simple form when focusing on completion (breakfast finished), not duration.
quizActivities.explanation: Past Perfect Simple emphasizes completed actions before another past moment. The breakfast was finished before you woke up.

quizActivities.question: What shows a long activity that caused a visible result?
quizActivities.sentence: I ____ emails all morning — my eyes hurt!
quizActivities.hint: The result (eyes hurt) came from a long continuous activity. Use Past Perfect Continuous (had been + -ing).
quizActivities.explanation: Past Perfect Continuous shows a long activity in the past that caused a result. Writing for hours caused the eye pain.

quizActivities.question: Which structure correctly uses the signal word 'already'?
quizActivities.sentence: She ____ when I called.
quizActivities.hint: 'Already' in the past context is a magic word that screams Past Perfect. She left BEFORE you called.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Already' in past stories signals Past Perfect. She completed leaving before the phone call happened.

quizActivities.question: Which shows an experience that never happened before a specific past time?
quizActivities.sentence: I ____ sushi before 2018.
quizActivities.hint: 'Never...before [year]' is a Past Perfect signal. You CAN use exact years with Past Perfect, unlike Present Perfect!
quizActivities.explanation: 'Never...before + specific year' requires Past Perfect. This shows no experience up until that past moment (2018).

quizActivities.question: What's correct when using 'after' in past context?
quizActivities.sentence: After she ____ homework, she watched TV.
quizActivities.hint: With 'before' or 'after', Past Perfect is OPTIONAL! Both forms work, but Past Perfect sounds more professional.
quizActivities.explanation: The secret: 'after' and 'before' make the time order clear, so Past Perfect is optional. Both 'had finished' and 'finished' are correct!

quizActivities.question: Choose the correct structures for this story sequence:
quizActivities.sentence: When I ____ at the station, I realized I ____ my wallet at home, and the train ____.
options: arrived / had left / had already left
quizActivities.correctAnswer: arrived / had left / had already left
quizActivities.hint: Main action = Past Simple (arrived). Things that happened BEFORE = Past Perfect (had left wallet, train had left).
quizActivities.explanation: Story order: Use Past Simple for the main moment (arrived), Past Perfect for what happened before it (had left wallet, train had already left).

quizActivities.question: What emphasizes the duration with a long activity?
quizActivities.sentence: He ____ for hours — the kitchen was destroyed!
quizActivities.hint: Focus on the long activity that caused the mess. Use Past Perfect Continuous with 'for hours'.
quizActivities.explanation: Past Perfect Continuous emphasizes duration and the visible result. Cooking for hours caused the messy kitchen.

quizActivities.question: Which structure correctly expresses old habits that stopped?
quizActivities.sentence: I ____ smoke, but I quit 5 years ago.
quizActivities.hint: 'Used to' shows past habits or states that stopped. It works with BOTH actions AND states.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Used to' expresses past habits that no longer happen. It clearly contrasts past and present: you smoked before, but not now.

quizActivities.question: What form shows repeated actions with nostalgia?
quizActivities.sentence: Every weekend we ____ go fishing.
quizActivities.hint: 'Would' + time expression (every weekend) shows repeated past actions with emotion/nostalgia. Only works with ACTION verbs!
quizActivities.explanation: 'Would' expresses repeated past actions, often with nostalgia. 'Every weekend' provides the time context needed for 'would'.

quizActivities.question: Which question form is grammatically correct for past habits?
quizActivities.sentence: ____ live in Jakarta?
quizActivities.hint: Questions with 'used to' follow: DID + subject + USE TO (no 'd' because 'did' already shows past).
quizActivities.explanation: In questions, 'used to' becomes 'use to' (without 'd') because 'did' already carries the past tense: 'Did you use to'.

quizActivities.question: Advanced: What's the correct form for a past state (not action)?
quizActivities.sentence: She ____ be shy, but now she's very confident.
quizActivities.hint: The golden rule: 'would' ONLY works with ACTIONS. For states (be, have, like), you MUST use 'used to'.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Be shy' is a STATE, not an action. 'Would' cannot be used with states—only 'used to' works here. Wrong: 'would be'.

quizActivities.question: Identify the error in this sentence:
quizActivities.sentence: When I arrived, the train ____.
options: had left (correct - shows train left first)
quizActivities.correctAnswer: had left (correct - shows train left first)
quizActivities.hint: Without Past Perfect, there's no clear time order. The train left BEFORE you arrived—use 'had left'.
quizActivities.explanation: Common mistake: using only Past Simple for two past actions. Use Past Perfect (had left) to show which happened first.

quizActivities.question: Which form best shows both forms are possible for certain verbs?
quizActivities.sentence: They ____ in Paris for 10 years before moving.
options: had lived / had been living (both correct)
quizActivities.correctAnswer: had lived / had been living (both correct)
quizActivities.hint: Live, work, study, teach → BOTH Simple and Continuous work with Past Perfect for duration!
quizActivities.explanation: With verbs like live, work, study, teach, both Past Perfect Simple and Continuous are correct for duration. Meaning is almost identical.

quizActivities.question: Complete the sequence with correct past forms:
quizActivities.sentence: She was happy because she ____ the exam, and she ____ for it for months.
quizActivities.hint: Both actions happened before 'was happy'. Use Past Perfect for completion (passed) and Past Perfect Continuous for duration (studying for months).
quizActivities.explanation: The reason (passing and studying) happened before the happiness. Use Past Perfect for the result and Past Perfect Continuous for the duration.

quizActivities.question: What negative form correctly shows something didn't happen before?
quizActivities.sentence: I ____ snow before I moved to Canada.
quizActivities.hint: 'Never...before [past moment]' signals Past Perfect negative. The experience didn't happen until that point.
quizActivities.explanation: Past Perfect negative (had never + past participle) shows an experience that didn't happen before a specific past moment.

quizActivities.question: Which shows the correct use with a time expression?
quizActivities.sentence: When I was young, I ____ ride my bike every day.
quizActivities.hint: 'Ride' is an action verb + time context (when I was young). Both 'would' and 'used to' work for repeated past actions!
quizActivities.explanation: For repeated ACTIONS with time context, both 'would' and 'used to' are correct. 'Would' adds nostalgia; 'used to' is more neutral.

quizActivities.question: What's the correct Past Perfect form with duration?
quizActivities.sentence: By 2020, he ____ in London for 8 years.
quizActivities.hint: 'By 2020' (past deadline) + 'for 8 years' (duration) = Past Perfect. Use 'had been' even though 'be' is not typically continuous.
quizActivities.explanation: Even with non-continuous verbs like 'be', use Past Perfect for duration up to a past moment. 'By 2020' signals Past Perfect.

quizActivities.question: Which correctly shows annoyance about a repeated past action?
quizActivities.sentence: My brother ____ steal my toys!
quizActivities.hint: 'Would' shows repeated actions with strong emotion (annoyance, nostalgia). 'Always' emphasizes the repetition.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Would always' expresses repeated past actions with emotion—perfect for showing annoyance about a sibling's behavior!

quizActivities.question: What structure shows ownership duration up to a past point?
quizActivities.sentence: We ____ that car for 10 years before it broke.
quizActivities.hint: 'For 10 years' + ownership ending in the past = Past Perfect. Use 'had had' (auxiliary + past participle of 'have').
quizActivities.explanation: Past Perfect with duration uses 'had + past participle'. For 'have', this becomes 'had had'—showing 10 years of ownership before the car broke.

quizActivities.question: Which shows the first time experiencing something in the past?
quizActivities.sentence: It was the first time I ____ the sea.
quizActivities.hint: 'The first time...was' is a magic phrase that forces Past Perfect. It shows no previous experience before that moment.
quizActivities.explanation: 'The first time' signals Past Perfect because it refers to all time before that moment. You hadn't seen it before then.

quizActivities.question: What form avoids the common Indonesian error?
quizActivities.sentence: I ____ never ____ snow before 2015.
quizActivities.hint: Common mistake: 'had never see' (missing -n). Correct: 'had never SEEN' (past participle ends in -n).
quizActivities.explanation: The error 'had never see' is common. Always use past participle after 'had': had seen, had done, had written (not see, do, write).

quizActivities.question: Which correctly uses 'until then' as a signal word?
quizActivities.sentence: I didn't know about computers ____ I started university.
quizActivities.hint: 'Until then' and similar phrases signal Past Perfect context. They show a state continuing up to a past moment.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Until then' signals a boundary in the past, often used with Past Perfect to show when something changed or started.

quizActivities.question: Advanced: What's the most dramatic and professional form?
quizActivities.sentence: Before I met Lisa, I ____ fallen in love.
quizActivities.hint: With 'before', Past Perfect is optional BUT sounds more professional and dramatic. Use 'had never' for impact!
quizActivities.explanation: While 'never fell' is acceptable, 'had never fallen' sounds more professional, dramatic, and native-like—perfect for storytelling!

quizActivities.question: Complete with the correct contrast between continuous and simple:
quizActivities.sentence: He ____ three emails (result), but he ____ all morning (tired).
quizActivities.hint: Simple = completed/countable result (3 emails). Continuous = long activity causing tiredness. Both use Past Perfect.
quizActivities.explanation: Past Perfect Simple shows completed results (had written 3 emails). Past Perfect Continuous shows long duration causing a state (had been writing → tired).

spellingActivities.hint: Completed earlier than expected (in the past)
spellingActivities.sentence: By the time I arrived, the train had ___ left.

spellingActivities.hint: Not at any time before that past moment
spellingActivities.sentence: I had ___ seen snow before I moved to Japan.

spellingActivities.hint: Time word that often goes with Past Perfect
spellingActivities.sentence: I had finished my homework ___ the movie started.
She ___ finished her project when the teacher collected it.

spellingActivities.hint: The strongest signal for Past Perfect
spellingActivities.sentence: ___ we got to the cinema, the film had started.

spellingActivities.hint: Past habits and states that stopped
spellingActivities.sentence: I ___ live in a small village when I was a child.

spellingActivities.hint: Repeated actions in the past (storytelling gold)
spellingActivities.sentence: Every weekend we ___ go to the beach.
She was tired because she ___ studying all morning.

spellingActivities.hint: Feeling sorry about something in the past (I wish I had…)
spellingActivities.sentence: My biggest ___ is that I didn’t study harder.

spellingActivities.hint: The time when you 'used to' and 'would' do many things
spellingActivities.sentence: In my ___, I would play outside until dark.
